SEARCH
Package ardat.tree

Class ArchiveEntityProcessor

java.lang.Object
ardat.tree.ArchiveEntity
ardat.tree.ArchiveEntityDecorator
ardat.tree.ArchiveEntityProcessor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Closeable, AutoCloseable
Direct Known Subclasses:
AESEntity, PrettyEntity
public abstract class ArchiveEntityProcessor extends ArchiveEntityDecorator
ArchiveEntityProcessor is an extension of ArchiveEntityDecorator class, that provides encoding and decoding of data accessed through ArchiveEntityDecorator.getContent(ByteBuffer). Encoding and decoding happens unbeknownst to the client via invocation of getContent(ByteBuffer), thus encapsulating the entire process. The concrete implementation must implement the encoding and decoding methods, so that decode(encode(x)) == x.

ArchiveEntityProcessor initializes and stores two buffers: one containing the bytes read from getComponent().getContent(), the second one contains the bytes provided by encode(ByteBuffer, ByteBuffer) or decode(ByteBuffer, ByteBuffer), which were processed but not yet sent to the client via getContent(ByteBuffer) due to the buffer size difference.
The concrete implementation must specify the lengths of these two buffers through getPreferredUnprocessedWindowSize() and getPreferredProcessedWindowSize(). ArchiveEntityProcessor guarantees that the first buffer will be filled unless there is no data left in the underlying entity, but the concrete implementation doesn't have to process all bytes it gets, allowing it to implement a silent header.

The silent header is a set of bytes appended to the end of the data stream of the underlying archive entity and known only to the concrete implementation. In AESEntity a silent header is a message digest ( hash ) at the end of the encoded data. AESEntity.encode(ByteBuffer, ByteBuffer) encrypts the incoming data and when there is no data left in the underlying entity it simply attaches the computed message digest of the unencrypted data to the end of the output buffer.
When the data is decrypted using AESEntity.decode(ByteBuffer, ByteBuffer) it doesn't process the last 32 bytes ( the length of SHA-256 ) immediately but instead cashes them. The next time decode() is called it processes the cashed 32 bytes alongside the new ones, but it again cashes the last 32 bytes, unless the underlying entity has no data left. When it happens it compares the computed hash with the attached one and if they don't match it throws an exception that the data has been corrupted.
As you can see the fact that AESEntity modified the data in encode() and decode() beyond simple encryption and decryption is hidden from the client.

The structure of the silent header and the necessity to implement it at all is up to the concrete implementation.

    decode(ByteBuffer in, ByteBuffer out)
    Decode the information passed through the input buffer and write it to the output buffer.
    It's guaranteed that the length of the input buffer is getPreferredUnprocessedWindowSize() and the length of the output buffer is getPreferredProcessedWindowSize() and that the in buffer is filled unless the underlying stream has no data left.

    • encode

      protected abstract int encode(ByteBuffer in, ByteBuffer out) throws IOException
      Encode the information passed through the input buffer and write it to the output buffer.
      It's guaranteed that the length of the input buffer is getPreferredUnprocessedWindowSize() and the length of the output buffer is getPreferredProcessedWindowSize() and that the input buffer is filled unless the underlying stream has no data left.
      Parameters:
      in - the bytes read from the underlying entity
      out - the buffer to write the encoded data to
      Returns:
      the number of encoded data in bytes
      Throws:
      IOException - if some I/O errors occur

    • decode

      protected abstract int decode(ByteBuffer in, ByteBuffer out) throws IOException
      Decode the information passed through the input buffer and write it to the output buffer.
      It's guaranteed that the length of the input buffer is getPreferredUnprocessedWindowSize() and the length of the output buffer is getPreferredProcessedWindowSize() and that the in buffer is filled unless the underlying stream has no data left.

      out - the buffer to write the decoded data to
      Returns:
      the number of decoded data in bytes
      Throws:
      IOException - if some I/O errors occur

    • getPreferredUnprocessedWindowSize

      protected abstract int getPreferredUnprocessedWindowSize()
      The size of the first buffer passed to encode() and decode(). The size is accessed when ArchiveEntityProcessor is initialized and doesn't change after.
      Returns:
      the size of the first buffer passed to encode() and decode()

    • getPreferredProcessedWindowSize

      protected abstract int getPreferredProcessedWindowSize()
      The size of the second buffer passed to encode() and decode(). The size is accessed when ArchiveEntityProcessor is initialized and doesn't change after.
      Returns:
      the size of the second buffer passed to encode() and decode()
